title: Hidden Single (Version 1)
statementHtml:
The two versions have different constraints on tt, nn, and the maximum number of queries, and solving one of the two versions does not necessarily solve the other. You may want to read both versions. Hacks are disabled in both versions.

This is an interactive problem.

There is a hidden array a1,a2,…,a2n−1a1,a2,…,a2n−1 containing all the numbers from 11 to nn, and all of them appear twice except one (which only appears once).

You can ask queries in the following format, where SS is a subset of {1,2,…,2n−1}{1,2,…,2n−1} and xx is an integer in [1,n][1,n]:

Find the number appearing exactly once, using at most 4n+2⌈log2n⌉4n+2⌈log2⁡n⌉ queries. You don't need to find its position.

Note that the interactor is not adaptive, which means that the hidden array does not depend on the queries you make.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤40001≤t≤4000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (1≤n≤3001≤n≤300) — the maximum value in the hidden array a1,a2,…,a2n−1a1,a2,…,a2n−1.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n2n2 over all test cases does not exceed 4⋅1054⋅105.

There are exactly 8080 tests in this problem (including the example).

Interaction

For each test case, first read a single integer nn. If the integer you read is −1−1, it means that the answer to the previous test case was wrong, and you should exit immediately.

You may ask up to 4n+2⌈log2n⌉4n+2⌈log2⁡n⌉ queries in each test case.

To ask a query, print a line in the format ? x |S| S_1 S_2 ... S_|S|? x |S| S_1 S_2 ... S_|S| with 1≤x≤n1≤x≤n, 1≤S1,S2,…,S|S|≤2n−11≤S1,S2,…,S|S|≤2n−1, and all the SiSi distinct.

As a response to the query, you will get 11 if the answer is yes, 00 if the answer is no, and −1−1 if you made an invalid query. You should exit immediately if you receive a −1−1.

To output an answer, you should print ! y! y, where yy is the number that appears exactly once. Printing the answer doesn't count as a query.

See the interaction example for more clarity.

If you ask too many queries, you ask a malformed query, or your answer is wrong, you will get Wrong answerWrong answer.

After printing a query, do not forget to output the end of line and flush the output. Otherwise, you will get Idleness limit exceededIdleness limit exceeded. To do this, use:

  • fflush(stdout)fflush(stdout) or cout.flush()cout.flush() in C++;
  • System.out.flush()System.out.flush() in Java;
  • flush(output)flush(output) in Pascal;
  • stdout.flush()stdout.flush() in Python;
  • see the documentation for other languages.

Note that the interactor is not adaptive, which means that the hidden arrays do not depend on the queries you make.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, n=2n=2, so the hidden array has length 2n−1=32n−1=3. One possible hidden array consistent with the interaction is [2,2,1][2,2,1], where 11 appears once and 22 appears twice.

#Contestant printsInteractor repliesExplanation
1? 1 2 1 20Query: does a1=1a1=1 or a2=1a2=1? No (they are both 22). Therefore 11 can appear at most once (only in position 33), so the number appearing exactly once must be 11.
2! 1Output the answer.

We have asked 11 query (printing the answer does not count as a query), which is less than the maximum allowed number of queries (4n+2⌈log2n⌉=104n+2⌈log2⁡n⌉=10).

22

In the second testcase, n=3n=3, so the hidden array has length 55. One possible hidden array consistent with the interaction is [1,2,3,2,1][1,2,3,2,1], where 33 appears once, and 11 and 22 appear twice.

#Contestant printsInteractor repliesExplanation
1? 1 2 1 41Check if a1a1 or a4a4 equals 11. Yes (a1=1a1=1).
2? 2 2 1 41Check if a1a1 or a4a4 equals 22. Yes (a4=2a4=2).
3? 2 1 21Check if a2=2a2=2. Yes.
4? 1 1 51Check if a5=1a5=1. Yes.
5! 3We know that 33 cannot appear neither in positions 11 and 44 (which contain 11 and 22 in some order), nor in positions 22 and 55 (which contain 22 and 11, respectively). So the answer must be 33.
